attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description:
·     A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 10 March 2025, to determine whether the stocks movement at the branch was well managed and to assess whether inventory management controls in place were operating effectively.

·       The exercise showed that:

ü  Polybags had a variance of +546 Pieces

ü  Bread stock had a variance of -211.5 Loaves.

ü  White flour had +20.44 Kgs.

ü  Utto had +4.20 Litres.

ü  Yeast and white ingredient had an immaterial variance of 0.41.

·       Below is the detailed summary of the audit findings:

Table 1:Stock count summary.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management implements adequate stock Management controls and improves checks on production materials’ usage and proper recording.
attributes.effect: The variances noted imply weak stock controls and lapses in monitoring raw materials and finished product movements.

value:
·       Bread shortfall was recovered, deductions of 120 loaves were raised and -78 pieces were due to +20.44 kgs of white flour.

·       We have also noted there was an issue with proper recording of raw materials, we will keep track of daily the movements in comparison with SAP balances.For bread stock we will ensure yield is recorded as per the branch set BOM.

·       Bread shortfall was recovered, deductions of 120 were raised and -78 pieces were due to +20.44 kgs of white flour.

·       We have noted also there was an issue with proper recording of raw materials, but manager have been advised to keep track of daily movements in comparison with SAP balances.For bread stock to ensure yield is recorded as per the branch set BOM.

·       In the prior audit report dated 08th February 2025, it was noted that:

ü  Polybags had a variance of +1,309 Pieces (exc. Akiyda used for FOC only)

ü  Finished product had a variance of -229 Loaves for bread produced by the branch.

ü  Yeast had a variance of +31.756 Pcs

ü  White flour had a variance of +37.457 Kgs and

White Ingredient had a variance of +0.756 Pcs
Current

attributes.title: Crates verification
attributes.description:
·       A review of the crate balances at the branch was done on 11 March 2025 to determine if crates movement controls in place were adequate to reduce the risk of loss of crates.

·       It was noted that the branch crates had + 45 crates as illustrated below:

Table 2:Crates movement.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management to follow up on the root cause of excess crates and return the crates to the source branch.
attributes.effect: The excess crates found indicate that there are possible errors in recording the movement of crates at the branch or receipt of unaccounted crates.

value: ·       There are many transfers of crates during the night at Dandora branches, we will do a stock of D 1,2&3 to check if there are branches with less.
·       There are many transfers of crates during the night at Dandora branches. We will do a stock of D 1,2&3 to check if there are branches with less.
In a prior audit dated 08th February 2025, the crates had a variance of +3 Crates.
Current

attributes.title: Bread Weights
attributes.description:
·       Packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market were randomly weighed to determine if they were of correct weight of 200g,400g,600g and 800g as per the KEBS standard weights.

·       Underweights were noted across the sampled varieties, however they were minimal, overall average weights were within the range as seen:

Ø  400 g white Bread had 19%

Ø  800g BT had 29%

Ø  600 BT had 17%

Ø  200 Mini loaf had 21%

·       Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:

Table 3:Bread weight Check.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch management to increase spot checks in the production area to ensure adherence to the required weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect: ·       The branch management to increase spot checks in the production area to ensure adherence to the required weight standards and weighing procedures.

value: ·       In comparison with the past there is an improvement, however sometimes there is a challenge, i.e. over-cooling, but we will do a follow-up to ensure the correct cooling process is adhered to.Breakdowns are also a key contributor, but the issue has been resolved.

·       In comparison with the past there is an improvement, however sometimes there is a challenge, i.e. over-cooling, but we will do a follow-up to ensure the correct cooling process is adhered to.Breakdowns are also a key contributor, but the issue has been resolved.

·     In the previous audit report, dated 08th February 2025 bread underweights were noted as follows:

ü  400g - 22%,

ü  600g - 0%,

ü  800g - 69%.
Current

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
·     An analysis of both production and market damages in the branch was done for a period of 28 days from 10 February 2025 to 10 March 2025 was done to determine if they were within the allowable threshold of 0.2% and 0.5 % respectively.

·       It was noted that production damages stood at 0.27% of total production, which was above the limit of 0.25 % with a cost implication of Ksh 16,185.56 while market damages were at 0.38% of total sales which was within the allowable threshold.

Table 4:Production Damages.

·       NB: The analysis is exclusive of 36 Oven damages.

Table 5:Market Damages.

·       N/B: Sales were more that loaves produced since there was no production between 12/02/2025-16/02/2025. (Roof renovations were being done, branch borrowed bread during this period)
attributes.recommendation: · Enhance controls and spot checks within the production process.
attributes.effect: ·       The production damages exceeded the allowable threshold, this implies that there were lapses in proper follow-up of correct production procedures leading to excess damages.Market damages was within the allowable threshold.

value:
·     ·       Excess production damages were contributed by failure to follow correct flow of production process, especially on rotation of baking tins but the unused tins have been set aside.

·       There has also been a challenge of mixer breakdowns that have disrupted the mixing process, the current mixer is not automatic hence sometimes it becomes a challenge to the mixer.Market Damages are within range, but we are still watching out on some routes and Mini shop to reduce bread mishandling.

·       Excess production damages were contributed by failure to follow correct flow of production process, especially on rotation of baking tins but the unused tins have been set aside.

·       There has also been a challenge of mixer breakdowns that have disrupted the mixing process, the current mixer is not automatic hence sometimes it becomes a challenge to the mixer.

Market Damages are within range, but we are still watching out on some routes and Mini shop to reduce bread mishandling.
In the prior audit report dated 10th February 2025, it was noted that production damages were at 0.25% while market damages were at 0.32%.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       A review of the branch’s production efficiency for a period of 28 days from 10 February 2025-10 March 2025 was done to determine if production workers were achieving their standard rate of 4.3 bags per production worker.

·       It was noted that production efficiency was at 4.01 bags per production workers which was below the standard rate with a cost implication of KES.40,204.2, 37 extra workers were hired.

Table 6: Production efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to introduce controls to ensure optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect: The branch production workers were not optimally utilized, extra 37 workers were hired with a cost implication of KES 40,204.2.

value: We are trying to push the production workers towards achieving there set KPI.
We are trying to push the production workers towards achieving there set KPI.
The previous audit report dated 08th February 2025, it was noted that production efficiency was at 3.96 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An evaluation was carried out on the utilization of packers in the slicing section for a period of 28 days from 10 February 2025 -10 March 2025 to assess whether optimal performance was achieved, based on the company’s standard KPI of 97 crates per packer.

·       The evaluation showed that packing efficiency was at 93.72 crates per packer, an extra 10 workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.9,120.

Table 7:Packing Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management to ensure optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: Packers were being underutilized; an extra 10 workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.9,120.

value: I will ensure packers are hired based on prior shift targets. We have also noted an issue with workers’ emergency cases arising middle in the shift, we will keep track of the same to check if there are specific workers affected by this all the time.

The manager is advised to ensure packers are hired based on prior shift targets. We have also noted an issue with workers’ emergency cases arising middle in the shift, we will keep track of the same to check if there are specific workers affected by this all the time.
In the previous audit report dated 08th March 2025 it was noted that packing efficiency was at 93.75 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period of 28 days from 10 February to 10 March 2025 was done to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.

·       The following were noted:

ü  The average yield was 193.04 loaves per bag

ü  Average production was 94.17 bags equivalent to 96.09% of the set target of 98 bags.

ü  Utto units’ consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1

ü   528 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:

Table 8:Mixing chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch management minimizes remix cases by adhering to the set procedures.
attributes.effect: ·       The high number of remixes imply lapses in following the set procedures in the production process.Average yield was within the range, production target achievement of 96.09 % indicates that there is room for improvement.

value: ·       Remixes happen occasionally whenever there are oven breakdowns and power disruptions.Production target is affected by production efficiency.
·       Remixes happen occasionally whenever there are oven breakdowns and power disruptions.Production target is affected by production efficiency.

·       In the prior audit report dated 08th February 2025 it was noted that:

ü  Average yield was at 193.17 loaves per Bag.

ü  Utto consumption to bags was 1:1

ü  1518 Cases of remixes were noted.

ü  Production target was at 95% of the branch capacity of 98 bags.
Current

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balances as at 11.03.2025 was done to determine if there were any instances of long outstanding debtors that could lead to bad debts.

·        A total of Kshs 82,222 debtors’ balances were noted, however most were those of institutions except for one customer with a pending credit note of Kshs 438. as seen below:
attributes.recommendation: ·       Follow up on pending balance for clearance.
attributes.effect: Debt balances were minimal, therefore well controlled; however, efforts should be made to recover the pending balance

value: One customer with one pending credit notes of 438, other balances are those of institutions.
One customer with one pending credit notes of 438, other balances are those of institutions.
The previous audit noted that all customers had nil balance except for Institutions with a balance of KES 6,559.
Current

attributes.title: Vehicle fuel consumption
attributes.description:
·       A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 28 days from 1 February to 28 February 2025.

·       It was noted that fuel consumption was within the range, however there were few vehicles that consumed more but minimal fuel as illustrated below in Appendix 1.
attributes.recommendation: Maintain and enhance the fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: Excess Vehicle fuel consumed implies that the company incurred extra cost.

value: ·       Minimal variations occur whenever there are breakdowns and vehicles are recalled to the workshop for repairs resulting in incomplete journey.We will ensure extra fuel is deducted when issuing next fuel.

· Minimal variations occur whenever there are breakdowns and vehicles are recalled to the workshop resulting in incomplete journey.Manager is advised to ensure extra fuel is deducted when issuing next fuel.
In the prior audit report dated 08th of February 2025, it was noted that all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard.
